description: From Middle English, borrowed from Old French fable, from Latin fābula, from fārī (“to speak, say”) + -bula (“instrumental suffix”). See ban, and compare fabulous, fame. Doublet of fabula.

entries.meaning: A fictitious narrative intended to enforce some useful truth or precept, usually with animals, etc. as characters; an apologue. Prototypically, Aesop's Fables.
Any story told to excite wonder; common talk; the theme of talk.
The plot, story, or connected series of events forming the subject of an epic or dramatic poem.

verbs.description: fable (third-person singular simple present fables, present participle fabling, simple past and past participle fabled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To compose fables; hence, to write or speak fiction; to write or utter what is not true.
(transitive, archaic) To make up; to devise, and speak of, as true or real; to tell of falsely; to recount in the form of a fable.
examples: Synonyms: make up, invent, feign, devise
